Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 47068−001 
Regional–Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
March 2013 
 
 
 
 
Selected Evaluation Studies for 2013

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CAPE  –  country assistance program evaluation 
CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
DMC  –  developing member country 
EAP  –  evaluation approach paper 
IED  –  Independent Evaluation Department 
RCI  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance 
(RDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (agriculture and rural sector 
development, energy sector development, finance 
sector development, preprimary and basic 
education, road transport, trade and services) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency 
and enabling business environment), capacity 
development (institutional development), 
governance (public administration), regional 
cooperation and integration (cross-border 
infrastructure) 
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high), national (medium) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Director General  V. Thomas, Independent Evaluation Department (IED) 
Advisor  V. Reppelin-Hill, IED 
 
Team leader  J.G. Tubadeza, Evaluation Specialist (Operations Coordination), IED 
Team members  L. Calderon, Evaluation Assistant, IED  
  R. Lumain, Senior Evaluation Officer, IED   
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

CONTENTS 
 
Page 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
 
II.  ISSUES  1 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  2 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome  2 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  5 
 
IV.  THE RANKING VICE−PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION  5 
 
 
APPENDIXES 
 
1.  Design and Monitoring Framework                                                                                  6 
 
2.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan                                                                                 8 
 
3.  Outline of Terms of Reference for Consultants                                                                9

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the work program of 
the Independent Evaluation Department (IED) for 2013−2015, with effect from 7 December 2012.1 
IED’s yearly program devotes more effort to higher-level evaluations covering multiple countries, 
sectors, and themes to complement project evaluations.2 These evaluations also emphasize a more 
strategic perspective to ensure that ADB’s directions and operations are captured and supported by 
more intense knowledge and outreach activities to maximize usefulness and impact. This research 
and development technical assistance (TA) for Selected Evaluation Studies for 2013 will cover a time 
slice of the 2013−2015 program cycle, with a focus on the studies initiated in 2013.3 It will fund select 
evaluations  supporting  both  ADB  operational  programs  (i.e.,  country  evaluations  and  sector 
assessments)  and  knowledge  programs  (i.e.,  thematic  and  corporate  evaluations,  impact 
evaluations, and topical working papers). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Strategy 2020and its results framework put increased emphasis on accountability and results 
 
by defining clear objectives and putting a mechanism in place to monitor progress.4 This TA will help 
IED supply evaluative feedback on the effectiveness of ADB operations in order to gauge the 
continued relevance and effectiveness of Strategy 2020 in several important thematic areas, and in 
one country, Tajikistan. 
 
3.  Strengthening  regional  cooperation  and  integration.  The  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Integration (RCI) Strategy adopted in 2006 set forth an explicit and integrated development approach 
to RCI.5 It identifies ADB’s priorities, elaborates on its role in supporting and promoting RCI, and 
delineates organizational responsibilities for implementation. Strategy 2020 reaffirmed the overall 
strategic directions outlined in the RCI strategy and set a long-term target of increasing RCI-related 
lending to at least 30% of ADB operations by 2020. A proposed thematic evaluation study will assess 
the design and implementation of the RCI strategy to provide broad guidance for future ADB regional 
operations. It will try to address the following questions: In what ways and how effectively did ADB 
integrate RCI into its operations in terms of the modalities used in different regional, subregional, and 
country  contexts?  To  what  extent  have  ADB’s  RCI  projects  achieved  their  intended  outputs, 
outcomes,  and  impacts?  How  has  ADB  coordinated  with  other  agencies  involved  in  RCI  and 
monitored the progress of such activities? Is ADB on track to achieve the Strategy 2020 RCI lending 
target? How can the RCI strategy be strengthened to enhance development effectiveness, in line 
with Strategy 2020?  
 
4.  Implementing the safeguard policy. ADB’s safeguard policy is embodied in its Safeguard 
Policy Statement issued in July 2009.6 ADB’s environmental and social safeguards are a cornerstone 
of its support for inclusive economic growth and environmental sustainability. The objectives of the 
policy are to avoid or, when avoidance is not possible, to minimize or mitigate adverse project 
                                                
1 The work program is driven by several main considerations: (i) providing timely input to the formulation of future 
policies, strategies, and programs of ADB; (ii) providing real-time feedback during loan processing and implementation; 
(iii) undertaking evaluation capacity building of regional departments and developing member countries; and (iv) 
contributing to knowledge solutions.  
2 IED’s major evaluations include thematic, corporate, real-time, and impact evaluation studies;  evaluation knowledge 
studies; and country and regional evaluations. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 February 2013. 
4 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila. 
http://www.adb.org/documents/strategy-2020-working-asia-and-pacific-free-poverty 
5 Its four pillars include separate but interrelated activities: (i) cross-border infrastructure and related software; (ii) trade 
and  investment  cooperation  and  integration;  (iii)  monetary  and  financial  cooperation  and  integration;  and  (iv) 
cooperation in regional public goods, i.e., prevention of communicable diseases and environmental degradation. 
6  ADB.  2009.  Policy  Paper:  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Manila.  http://www.adb.org/documents/safeguard-policy-
statement

2 
 
impacts on the environment and affected people, and to help borrowers strengthen safeguard 
systems and develop a capacity to manage environmental and social risks. The policy also stipulates 
that IED conduct two reviews. The first, after 3 years, will be an operational review to assess 
progress on the use and effectiveness of country safeguards systems, and implementation and 
effectiveness of safeguard requirements for financial intermediation projects. The second review, 
after  5  years,  will  assess  the  effectiveness  of  the  2009  policy  in  achieving  ADB's  safeguard 
objectives. During the Asian Development Fund XI replenishment negotiations, donors requested 
IED to report on ADB’s safeguards implementation during the fund’s midterm review in October 
2014. In light of this, the evaluation will proceed in two phases: an operational review due around 
end-2013, and a thematic evaluation on the effectiveness of the 2009 policy due by mid-2014.  
 
5.  Evaluating the role of technical assistance operations. TA operations can be financed by 
grants or, more rarely, loans through ADB’s main fund sources or a number of special funds provided 
by individual donors. ADB TA operations are important as these facilitate capacity development, 
knowledge building, and project preparation in developing member countries (DMCs). TA resources 
are also used to address global issues (such as regional cooperation or climate change). As such, 
TA operations in ADB and other international financial institutions are increasing in importance, 
complementing  the  traditional  loan  portfolios.  Many  institutions  are  interested  in  improving  the 
strategic relevance, efficiency, and effectiveness of this instrument. In this context, the Development 
Effectiveness Committee requested that IED review the role of TA in ADB and assess how it can 
best contribute to strengthening the development effectiveness of ADB operations. 
 
6.  Education  impact  evaluation.  IED  will  conduct  an  impact  evaluation  on  the  learning 
outcomes of school facilities improvement, teacher training, and stipends for female secondary 
school students. Its findings will seek to provide direction for future investments in strengthening 
secondary education in Bangladesh, by identifying what works and what does not. This will enable 
the government to plan appropriate interventions, and assist ADB staff to design better projects, 
taking into account learning outcomes. The study may evaluate differential impacts from project 
interventions by assessing the performance of schools, teachers, and students in project areas that 
did not receive such treatment (i.e., counterfactuals). Its focus will be on teachers and students from 
grades  6–10,  assessing  learning  outcomes  in  mathematics,  science,  computer  literacy,  and  a 
language (Bangla or English), depending on the school’s medium of instruction. Data permitting, the 
evaluation may also assess differences in learning outcomes across project schools (i.e., public and 
private schools, rural and urban schools).  
 
7.  Country assistance program evaluation: Tajikistan. The proposed country assistance 
program evaluation (CAPE) for Tajikistan will be the first assessment of ADB country strategies and 
programs in Tajikistan. It aims to draw lessons and make recommendations for the next country 
partnership strategy (CPS), and provide an objective assessment and rating of the performance of 
ADB’s assistance to Tajikistan—and identify factors affecting such performance.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact of the TA will be improved development effectiveness of ADB operations, policies, 
strategies,  and  business  processes.  Its  expected  outcome  will  be  increased  use  of  evaluation 
findings,  lessons,  and  recommendations  by  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors  and  the  Board’s 
Development Effectiveness Committee, by ADB Management and operations, and also by the public.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  An  evaluation  approach  paper  (EAP)  detailing  the  rationale,  objective  and  scope, 
methodologies  to  be  used,  resource  requirements,  terms  of  reference  for  consultants,  and 
dissemination plan will be prepared for each major evaluation under this TA before a study begins. A 
concept paper may be prepared in cases where diagnostic work is needed prior to finalizing the EAP, 
or where a country sector assessment is more conveniently conducted ahead of the CAPE into 
which it will ultimately feed. Consultant recruitment may begin when either a draft EAP or a concept 
paper is signed off by IED’s director general for interdepartmental review.7 All major IED evaluations 
are intended to provide inputs for milestone reviews and decisions by ADB’s Board and Management 
and the IED will schedule the studies to meet the relevant deadlines. Once completed, major 
evaluation reports are circulated to the Board and Management and normally discussed by the 
Development Effectiveness Committee.  
 
10.  Country  assistance  program  evaluations,  sector  assessments,  and  validations  of 
country partnership strategy final reviews. IED undertakes evaluation studies in direct response 
to  ADB  country  operations  (i.e., IED’s  derived  program). These  comprise  preparing  CAPEs  or 
validating CPS final reviews for select DMCs, provided the date of the CPS into which these are to 
feed is announced to IED in sufficient time.8 The TA will finance at least one CAPE (Tajikistan) and 
validate several CPS final reviews (e.g., Bhutan, Cambodia, and Regional Southeast Asia). The 
CAPE will evaluate ADB support to the country and cover ADB strategy, policy dialogue, completed 
and ongoing projects and TA, and ADB performance. It will provide ADB and the DMC with a basis 
for determining the future CPS. When appropriate, country sector assessments will provide inputs 
during the preparation of a CAPE. Each sector assessment will evaluate ADB performance within a 
given sector in the country, focusing again on strategy, policy dialogue, ongoing and completed 
projects and TA, and performance. 
 
11.  Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy and related operations. The thematic 
evaluation study will review the design and implementation of ADB’s RCI strategy, from its inception 
in 2006 up to the end of 2013. The study will assess the responsiveness, results, and relevance of 
the RCI strategy and RCI-related elements of Strategy 2020, to draw out useful lessons for future 
operations. The study will initially undertake a desk review of project documents, evaluation reports, 
and pertinent literature. It will also take stock of previous regional evaluations to learn from best 
practices of development partners in RCI-related work. The achievements will also be assessed in 
relation to the RCI strategy’s results framework and the RCI-specific strategic priorities of Strategy 
2020. This will include validation of the findings of the ongoing ADB self-assessment of its RCI 
strategy (being undertaken by the Office of Regional Economic Integration). The study will assess 
ADB’s regional operations in terms of their effectiveness in delivering envisaged outputs, outcomes, 
and  impacts.  The  evaluation  will  involve  an  in-depth  review  of  activities  (e.g.,  projects,  policy 
dialogue, and other forms of cooperation) across the four RCI pillars in the five regions. Perception 
surveys and key informant interviews of regional DMC stakeholders and other development partners 
undertaking RCI-related work will also be conducted to elicit views about ADB’s RCI achievements.  
 
                                                
7  IED considers consultant recruitment appropriate also in cases when: (i) concept papers are approved or circulated 
interdepartmentally for sector or thematic assessments to be done prior to, but in the context of, CAPEs; and (ii) 
concept papers are approved or circulated interdepartmentally to hire consultants for diagnostic work or background 
papers in the context of other evaluations.  
8  A CAPE is conducted before preparing a CPS, but not all CPSs are preceded by CAPEs. If the work program of IED 
does not include a CAPE for a country that is due for a new CPS, IED will validate a CPS final review. The CPS final 
review validation report then serves as the equivalent of a CAPE for the purpose of CPS preparation.

4 
 
12.  Implementation of the safeguard policy. The thematic evaluation study will assess ADB 
safeguard operations since the adoption of the Safeguard Policy Statement in 2009.9 The focus will 
be on DMC implementation of safeguards, ADB’s supervision and support, its outcomes on the 
ground, gaps in compliance, and gaps in equivalence between ADB’s safeguards and the country’s 
policies and organizational practices. The study will also give special attention to ADB TA projects 
that are implemented to address compliance and equivalence issues, and to develop capacity in this 
field. It will look into the staffing and resources of ADB to manage safeguards in its projects. The 
study will include a review of the portfolio to discern trends in the application of the policy by region, 
income level, sector, and time. In-depth reviews of selected projects will also be carried out on the 
ground, possibly in five DMCs—in Southeast Asia, South Asia, Central and West Asia, East Asia, 
and  the  Pacific—to  draw  out  key  lessons.  ADB  documents  such  as  environmental  impact 
assessments, environmental management plans, resettlement plans and frameworks, indigenous 
peoples plans and frameworks, and related documents will be examined. The evaluation will also 
look at several types of DMC organizations that apply country safeguard systems, including financial 
intermediaries, and how these interact with ADB.  
 
13.  Technical assistance approach and methodology. The evaluation study will assess the 
role of TA by looking at policy and guidance documents, emerging trends in TA, and a review of ADB 
performance.  The  study  will  (i)  review  and  assess  ADB’s  guiding  policy  and  implementation 
documents for TA operations (i.e., the 2008 TA policy paper10 and 2011 Operations Manual11); (ii) 
review  ADB’s  business  processes  for  TA  approval  and  implementation  (including  the  use  of 
consultants); (iii) compare ADB’s TA practices with those of other international financial institutions 
(including independent evaluations related to TA); and (iv) assess the performance of ADB TA in its 
various forms (e.g., capacity development TA, policy and advisory TA, research and development 
TA, project preparatory TA). The evaluation will involve (i) desk review of key documents and a 
benchmarking exercise, (ii) portfolio analyses and a review of self and independently evaluated TA 
projects, (iii) key informant interviews, and (iv) a few country case studies.  
 
14.  Impact evaluations. The TA will support at least two rigorous impact evaluations. The 
Secondary Education Sector Improvement Project (Loan 1690-BAN[SF]) in Bangladesh has been 
identified as a potential candidate for such evaluation, and its suitability will be confirmed through a 
scoping mission in consultation with the executing agency.12 The evaluation will comprise four steps: 
(i) literature review, (ii) secondary data analysis and identification of counterfactuals, (iii) primary data 
collection, and (iv) data analysis and report preparation. The study will build on data collected during 
the project’s implementation and identify relevant comparison groups (counterfactuals) based on 
secondary data and key informant interviews. The impact evaluation will adopt a mixed method 
approach encompassing both qualitative and quantitative techniques, and will be guided by data 
collected by the study team (i.e., a large survey of households and/or schools). For quantitative 
impacts, an instrumental variable, propensity score matching, or regression discontinuity approach 
will be adopted. The study will also take stock of the status of reform measures introduced under the 
ADB-supported project.  
15.  Other  sector  and  thematic  assessments,  and  topical  working  papers.  The  TA  will 
support  selected  country,  sector,  and/or  thematic  assessments  needed  to  feed  into  or  help 
disseminate the high-level or major evaluations in the IED work program. This will also include 
                                                
9 Timing of study preparation is in line with the Asian Development Fund donors’ requirement for evaluation feedback 
during the fund’s midterm review. IED will carry out the study from the second half of 2013 through the first half of 
2014. 
10 ADB. 2008. Increasing the Impact of the Asian Development Bank’s Technical Assistance Program. Manila. 
11 ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance. Operations Manual. OM D12/BP and D12/OP. Manila. 
12 ADB. 2008. Completion Report: Secondary Education Sector Improvement in Bangladesh. Manila.

5 
selective evaluative research on high impact topics of specific interest and relevance to DMCs 
through ―quick turnaround‖ topical working papers. 
 
16.  Evaluation  outreach  and  knowledge  sharing.  To  make  its  evaluation  products  more 
accessible and influential, IED will continue to disclose, disseminate, and share evaluation feedback 
on performance and lessons. It will support interactive knowledge-sharing events (i.e., conferences, 
seminars, workshops) on at least two completed major evaluations. These will be a venue for 
learning and showcasing of evaluation products; informing stakeholders of formative, summative, 
and prospective evaluation approaches, and findings and lessons. The learning events are to be held 
in selected DMCs in partnership with national think tanks, evaluation societies, public and/or nonprofit 
research institutions, and other partners. From each learning event, IED will also seek to develop 
communication and outreach products (such as podcasts, multimedia products, and synopses), to 
promote further  learning.  IED  will  also  continue  to  prepare  and  publish  syntheses,  briefs,  and 
occasional papers tailored to widen readership, and use new mediums for knowledge sharing (e.g., 
online readers, tablets) to extend the reach of its products.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,950,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The IED will implement it and supervise all 
planned studies. The studies will require the services of 34 international consultants for about 47 
person-months and 33 national consultants for about 68 person-months.13 The outline terms of 
reference for consulting requirements are in Appendix 3. More detailed terms of reference for each 
study will be developed for the EAP. ADB will engage consultants primarily on an individual basis in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
specific  services  required  from  consulting  firms  (e.g.,  for  surveys)  will  be  considered  during 
preparation of the EAP. 
 
19.  Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Tracking of study progress will be 
recorded through internal monitoring sheets on key milestone events, mission back-to-office reports, 
and ad hoc presentations or consultations on evaluation study findings. The TA outputs will be 
disseminated in accordance with IED’s evaluation policy, particularly with regard to public disclosure, 
dissemination, and lessons. The TA is scheduled to start on 1 May 2013, and expected to end by 30 
June 2015. Implementation arrangements will be flexible to accommodate alterations in IED’s work 
program or changes in response to priorities under Strategy 2020 and assistance provided from 
Asian Development Fund X and XI. ADB will obtain a no-objection from the DMC government before 
starting any activity financed under this TA in the territory of that country. 
 
IV.  THE RANKING VICE-PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
20.  The Ranking Vice-President, acting in the absence of the President, under the provisions of 
Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, recommends that the Board approve the provision of 
technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,950,000  on  a  grant  basis  for  Selected 
Evaluation Studies for 2013.  
                                                
13 The number of consultants and their inputs remain tentative. Consultant requirements will be reviewed during 
discussions on the concept paper or evaluation approach paper.

Appendix 3      9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Derived Program from Country Operations 
1.   Country assistance program evaluations, sector assessments, and validations of 
country partnership strategy final reviews (seven international consultants for a total of 13 
person-months  and  12  national  consultants  for  24  person-months).1  Country  assistance 
evaluations provide the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the developing member countries 
(DMCs) with a basis for determining the future country partnership strategy (CPS).2 Depending 
on country and sector requirements, sector and/or thematic assessments are undertaken to 
provide inputs to the main country assistance program evaluation (CAPE). Sector assessments 
will evaluate ADB's strategy, policy dialogue, ongoing and completed projects and technical 
assistance (TA), and performance within a given sector in a country. Their preparation will 
require the services of sector and/or theme specialists (both international and national). 
 
2.  International consultants (total of 8 person-months for CAPEs and their associated 
sector assessments and 5 person-months for validations of CPS final reviews). The consultants 
are expected to (i) update reviews of ADB-financed assistance programs and assess their 
relevance,  effectiveness,  efficiency,  sustainability,  and  their  impacts  on  strategic  sector 
objectives; (ii) undertake key informant interviews and conduct stakeholder surveys on the 
outcome and impact of ADB assistance, and discuss sector development issues and concerns 
with  executing  agencies  and  other  government  and  nongovernment  entities;  and  (iii)  help 
assess the validity of ADB’s sector development strategies in the study country. 
 
3.  National  consultants  (total  of  12  person-months  for  five  headquarters-based 
consultants  and  12  person-months  for  seven  in-country  experts).  National  evaluation 
consultants with previous exposure to sector development issues in the study country will be 
recruited  to  (i)  present  an  overview  of  the  relevance  and  implementation  of  ADB  sector 
strategies; (ii) assess and rate the achievement of project and program objectives, and the 
delivery of core sector, crosscutting, and thematic programs; (iii) comment on ADB’s institutional 
positioning and performance in a sector; (iv) organize and facilitate focus group discussions, 
workshops, and meetings; and (v) define important issues and lessons in a sector’s operations. 
 
B.  Knowledge Program 
 
1.  Thematic Evaluation Study 
 
4.      Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Strategy  and  related  operations  (three 
international consultants for a total of 8 person-months and four national consultants for a total 
of 7 person-months). The thematic evaluation study team will apply a mix of secondary, project 
and  survey data, and in-depth interviews to assess the design and implementation of ADB’s 
2006 RCI strategy.  
 
                                                
1  Estimates of consultant requirements are all tentative and will be reviewed during discussions of the concept paper 
or evaluation approach paper (main text, para. 9). 
2  A country assistance program evaluation (CAPE) is conducted before preparing a CPS, but not all CPSs are 
preceded by CAPEs. If the work program of the Independent Evaluation Department (IED) does not include a 
CAPE for a country that is due for a new CPS, IED will validate a CPS final review. The CPS final review validation 
report then serves as the equivalent of a CAPE for the purpose of CPS preparation.

10     Appendix 3 
 
5.  International consultants (total of 8 person-months for three international experts). 
Three international evaluation consultants with RCI and evaluation expertise will be recruited to 
help conduct the thematic evaluation. A policy specialist (3 person-months) will be recruited to 
assist the study team to assess the activities under pillars 3 and 4 of the RCI strategy, covering 
monetary and financial cooperation and integration, and regional public goods. An infrastructure 
specialist (3 person-months) will be recruited to assist the study team to assess the activities 
under pillar 1 on cross-border infrastructure and related software and to undertake field trips to 
selected project sites of completed regional projects. A trade specialist (2 person-months) will 
be recruited to assist the evaluation team to assess the activities under pillar 2 on trade and 
investment cooperation and integration. The international consultants will review ADB project 
documents,  participate  in  field  visits  to  conduct  interviews,  organize  sample  surveys  of 
multilateral financial institutions and clients, and prepare assigned sections of the thematic 
evaluation.  
 
6.  National consultants (total of 5 person-months for two headquarters-based consultants 
and 2 person-months for two in-country experts). The thematic evaluation will require four 
national  consultants.  An  ADB  headquarters-based  national  consultant  with  statistical  data 
analysis skills will be recruited to assist the evaluation team in reviewing project, TA, and other 
relevant documents (3 person-months). Another ADB headquarters-based national consultant 
will be engaged to assist the evaluation team in analyzing survey data (2 person-months). Two 
national in-country experts with RCI knowledge and experience will be recruited, one for the 
Southeast Asia region and the other for the Central and West Asia region (1 person-month 
each). They will provide background information, assist the evaluation team during its regional 
and/or country visits, and help conduct the surveys and collect local data and information. 
 
7.  Implementation of safeguard policy (two international consultants for a total of 6 
person-months and seven national consultants for a total of 16 person-months). The thematic 
evaluation study will evaluate safeguards performance by carrying out a portfolio analysis of 
projects  in  the  different  safeguards  categories  across  regions  and  at  different  times.  The 
thematic evaluation will reflect on the adequacy of the 2009 Safeguard Policy Statement in light 
of experiences derived from the portfolio analyses and case studies. Safeguards experiences 
from other multilateral agencies will be recounted and brought into the study. The evaluation 
team will be assisted by a team of experienced national and international consultants in the field 
of safeguards. 
 
8.  International consultants (total of 6 person-months for two international consultants). 
International consulting requirements will comprise a social specialist and an environmental 
specialist (3 person-months each). The consultants will work on both the portfolio analyses and 
the case studies, and bring in experiences from other multilateral agencies including the World 
Bank  and  International  Finance  Corporation,  African  Development  Bank,  and  European 
Investment Bank, etc. The study will investigate specific projects for best practice and those with 
key lessons to be learned through country case studies. The consultants will also help design a 
methodology to ascertain the impacts of the implementation of safeguards on the ground. They 
will travel to site locations so that field experiences can be included in the evaluation, and the 
model can be validated. DMCs, through relevant government ministries and local communities, 
will be interviewed about their experiences on specific projects. 
 
9.  National consultants (total of 6 person-months for two headquarters-based consultants 
and  10  person-months  for  five  in-country  experts).  Two  headquarters-based  national 
consultants—a database specialist and a research analyst—will conduct desk reviews including 
portfolio analysis, secondary data collection, literature reviews, internet search, etc. (3 person-

Appendix 3  11 
months each). Five national in-country experts (2 person-months each) will focus on elaborating 
the case studies in their own country and in their sectors of expertise.  
 
2.  Corporate Evaluation Study 
 
10.  Technical assistance approach and methodology (three international consultants for 
a total of 7 person-months and two national consultants for a total of 10 person-months). The 
corporate evaluation study  will assess the role of  ADB’s TA operations with emphasis on 
relevance and other criteria related to performance of the portfolio, such as the efficiency and 
effectiveness of ADB’s TA in all its categories.  
 
11.  International consultants (total of 7 person-months for three international consultants). 
The evaluation team will be assisted by three international consultants with development and 
evaluation expertise. A senior evaluator, with broad knowledge of development and TA, as well 
as experience working with different international financial institutions, will act as lead consultant 
and assist with a benchmarking study and assessment of ADB’s TA policy and guidelines, 
including the business processes related to approval and implementation (3 person-months). 
The consultant will also be part of the country visits and survey work. A second evaluator will be 
engaged to assist in undertaking the TA portfolio review (2 person-months). The third evaluator 
will be recruited to undertake a desk review of the country case studies and participate in the 
country visits (2 person-months).  
 
12.  National  consultants.  Two  national  consultants  will  be  recruited  for  research  and 
analytical work in ADB headquarters (5 person-months each). A headquarters-based national 
consultant with statistical data analysis skills will be recruited to assist the evaluation team in 
reviewing project and other relevant documents. A second national consultant will be engaged 
to assist with the portfolio, bench marking, country studies, and analyzing survey data. 
 
3.  Impact Evaluation 
 
13.   The TA will fund two impact evaluations (six international consultants for a total of 8 
person-months and four national consultants for a total of 7 person-months per study). Each 
rigorous  impact  evaluation  will  tentatively  require  the  services  of  a  team  of  international 
consultants comprising a sector or theme specialist (2 person-months), an econometrician (1.5 
person-months), and a peer reviewer (0.5 person-months). Two national evaluation consultants 
(total of 3.5 person-months) will help undertake the study.  
 
14.  The  international  sector  or  theme  specialist  will  provide  inputs  to  designing  the 
questionnaire for impact evaluation and sustainability analysis and to qualitative assessments 
on the effectiveness of project outputs. The international impact evaluation econometrician will 
help with quantitative estimates of project results, i.e., achieving project outcomes and impacts. 
A national in-country expert (1.5 person-months per study) will be recruited to carry out the 
individual and household surveys. A national evaluation consultant (2 person-months per study) 
will be engaged for research and analytical work in ADB headquarters. Specific tasks of the 
consultant will include, among others, desk review and content analysis, literature review on 
project impact, and data collection and analysis. 
 
4.  Topical Working Papers 
 
15.  The TA will support IED’s topical working papers series (three international consultants 
for  a  total  of  5  person-months).  As  part  of  its  evaluation  outreach,  ADB’s  Independent

12     Appendix 3 
 
Evaluation Department (IED) prepares ―quick turnaround‖ papers that are intended to draw out 
lessons  from  existing  and  ongoing  evaluations  (from  both  ADB  and  other  development 
partners), on topics of high operational relevance. International consultants cum advisers (with a 
high level of expertise and strong multilateral experience) will be engaged to assist staff in 
preparing short papers that provide an evaluative angle and connect past lessons to current and 
prospective situations.  
 
C.  Evaluation Outreach and Knowledge Sharing 
 
16.  The TA will support at least two interactive knowledge−sharing and learning events (e.g., 
about 10 international experts for at least 0.3 person-months, and four national consultants 
including two at ADB headquarters and two in country for about 1 person-month each). These 
aim to provide learning opportunities on priority development topics; to increase learning from 
evaluations and to enable policymakers and decision makers to interact meaningfully. For each 
learning event, IED will identify a host or collaborating partner in the DMC. These institutions will 
work with IED in hosting and organizing the knowledge events. In this context, IED will seek to 
build  knowledge  network  partnerships  with  premier  think  tanks,  research  organizations, 
evaluation associations, and academic institutions in the DMCs.  
 
17.  Panel-based forums will bring together three to four panelists to discuss issues and 
topics associated with the evaluation. A moderator will facilitate discussion among panelists, 
and between the panelists and audience. The media will be invited. The events will be audio- 
and/or video-recorded and disseminated as podcasts through online platforms. IED will share 
the details of the event and post-event materials through its website and social networking sites. 
These organizations will be asked to help organize and coordinate the event in cooperation with 
IED. An in-country events management coordinator will manage and oversee the event, in 
coordination  with  IED.  Policymakers,  representatives  of  public  and  nonprofit  research 
institutions, members of civil society, individual experts, and opinion makers will be invited to 
attend. 
 
18.  In-country events management coordinator (national, 1 person-month per event). 
The events management coordinator will be recruited to manage each knowledge-sharing and 
learning event. The coordinator will conceptualize, support, coordinate, and administer the event 
under the supervision and guidance of the counterpart event manager from the IED. The 
coordinator  must  have  experience  in  events  management  and  project  coordination  and 
administration, and preferably in organizing similar events. The coordinator will serve as the 
secretariat  for  the  event,  and  will  work  closely  with  the  identified  partner  or  collaborating 
institution within the host DMC, and help IED staff to conduct the learning event during their 
country visit. 
 
19.  Seminar  coordinator  (national,  1  person-month  per  event).  A  headquarters-based 
seminar coordinator will work closely with IED staff and local partners in the host countries to 
provide operations support for the seminars, including disbursement and liquidation of seminar 
expenses. The coordinator will provide technical, administrative, and logistical support for the 
timely and effective organization of the seminars.  
 
20.  Panelists (international, four experts for at least 3 person-days each per event). The 
knowledge-sharing  and  learning  event  will  require  inputs  of  several  panelists  who  will 
complement and catalyze new and creative ideas on development trends and paradigms, and 
emergent strategic thinking on development. They are required to have substantial knowledge 
on the theme(s) and topics of the specific event. The panelists will be notable academics,

Appendix 3  13 
development practitioners, researchers, government officials, and thought leaders in their own 
right; and have demonstrated credibility in their sphere of work or area of expertise. The 
panelists will have postgraduate academic qualifications, at least 10 years’ experience in their 
areas of expertise, and good communication skills. They  will be responsible for preparing 
materials and talking points, delivering presentations to communicate their ideas, and engaging 
in  discussion  with  the  event  audience.  They  will  be  available  to  participate  in  follow-up 
discussions  with  interest  groups,  officials,  and  stakeholders  in  the  DMCs  as  part  of  their 
involvement in the knowledge-sharing and learning event. 
  
21.  Moderator (international or national, one moderator for at least 3 person-days each per 
event). The moderator will be responsible for managing, directing, and facilitating the delivery of 
the panel discussion, and ensuring optimal participation throughout the event. The moderator 
will guide the panelists, suggest stimulating questions, and manage the overall flow of the 
discussion, guide and moderate the question and answer session, and provide a summary of 
key points raised during the discussion. The moderator must have substantive experience in 
facilitating  and  moderating  knowledge-sharing  and  learning  events,  and  exceptional 
communication skills. Knowledge and exposure on the theme of the event will be desirable.
author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CAPE  –  country assistance program evaluation 
CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
DMC  –  developing member country 
EAP  –  evaluation approach paper 
IED  –  Independent Evaluation Department 
RCI  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance 
(RDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (agriculture and rural sector 
development, energy sector development, finance 
sector development, preprimary and basic 
education, road transport, trade and services) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency 
and enabling business environment), capacity 
development (institutional development), 
governance (public administration), regional 
cooperation and integration (cross-border 
infrastructure) 
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high), national (medium) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Director General  V. Thomas, Independent Evaluation Department (IED) 
Advisor  V. Reppelin-Hill, IED 
 
Team leader  J.G. Tubadeza, Evaluation Specialist (Operations Coordination), IED 
Team members  L. Calderon, Evaluation Assistant, IED  
  R. Lumain, Senior Evaluation Officer, IED   
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
